_prev_prog_3.Description: Arkema Inc., Coating Resins, uses bulk monomers and ammonium hydroxide as part of its emulsion polymers process to produce water-borne latex.  An operating process is used to produce the latex, which is a non-flammable, non-toxic product.  The latex produced at this site is sold to coating manufacturers.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Arkema Inc has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Torrance Coating Resin plant in accordance with Section 2745.10 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and 40 CFR Part 68.  The Arkema Inc. facility in Torrance, CA is classified as a program Level 3 due to its participation in OSHA's Process Safety Management standards. In accordance with paragraph (a) of this section, the update has been prepared within 5 years of the date of the last submittal in 2012.  

The following activities were conducted in support of the RMP Update, in accordance with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP guidance for updates:

* The Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) for the facility was revised by Arkema using the HAZOP methodology.  

* The Offsite Consequence Analysis was determined using a current version of RMP*Comp.  The affected population and list of sensitive receptors was determined using MARPLOT v5.0.3 software.  

* The seismic analysis for the affected systems was reviewed for changes to the system, changes to the building codes that may impact affected systems, and implementation of recommendations made in the last seismic review.  

* The most recent compliance audit was conducted by the Torrance Fire Department, in accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations.  

This Executive Summary discusses the current status of each of the RMP program elements.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

Arkema has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  Arkema is committed to operating and maintaining all of the processes in a safe and responsible manner.  Arkema has implemented a combination of accident release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of its employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment.  These programs include both Arkema Responsible Care requirements and governmental requirements, such as EPA's RMP rule, and

the CalARP RMP requirements.





DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 

Arkema Coating Resin facility, located in Torrance, California, operates a latex emulsion manufacturing process that produces more than 100 million pounds of waterborne latex per year.  The waterborne latex produced at this site is utilized by the coatings industry to make latex-based paints, caulks, adhesives, and sealants.  The facility is recognized as a covered source under the RMP rule as the facility maintains quantities of regulated substances listed in the RMP rule above the applicable thresholds, Vinyl acetate, ammonia solution.  The facility does not maintain specified quantities of any RMP regulated flammable substances, but does utilize the following RMP regulated toxic substances at levels above threshold limits.





GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at Arkema facility in Torrance, California.  Arkema general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA and CalARP regulations as well as implementation of Arkema safety policies.  General accident prevention program consists of compliance with the following rules:

* California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program

* 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention (RMP rule)

* 40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan

* 40 CFR Part 355, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)



Compliance Audits

In accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations, a compliance audit was conducted by the Torrance Fire Department using a modified EPA RMP audit protocol.  The audit findings noted no deficiencies.   

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Arkema periodically conducts corporate and plant-led audits to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and Arkema requ

irements.



Contractor Safety Program 

Arkema uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. During procurement of contractor services, Company purchasing procedures require the verification of training, safety record, and if applicable, certifications and licenses. Prior to initiating work at the facility, contractors are required to attend a safety orientation, which is documented and records retained. Some contractors are required to work on or near process equipment; therefore, the facility has established procedures to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that are found during their work. At least one Arkema employee is assigned to each contractor. The Arkema employee is responsible for checking the work of each contractor to ensure Arkema procedures are followed. Safe Work Permitting practices are followed to ensure hazards and scope of work are reviewed with contractors working in the facility.



Employee Participation 

Arkema encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management, behavior based safety and accident prevention.  Arkema engages its employees through formal and informal means. The management of change process is an intranet-based workflow process that notifies affected employees of the change or changes. The technical support team reviews and approves changes before implementation.  A shift change meeting is conducted to discuss issues and concerns covering all aspects of the employee's work. Employees have access either through Arkema network to access information created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Employees are encouraged to participate in the ac

cident prevention program. In addition, employees are involved in other aspects of the operation including, but not limited to, periodic inspections, operating procedure creation, and incident investigations. Employees also participate in pre start-up safety reviews after periods of shutdown or before changes are implemented that affect the process.



Equipment Design 

Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements. 



Incident Investigation 

Arkema promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident by reviewing facts and developing corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The production leader is responsible for incident investigations at the facility.  No incidents occurred in the past 5 years involving RMP covered chemicals that required incident investigation.



Management of Change 

Arkema has a robust system to ensure that modifications to facilities and processes are reviewed by the appropriate technical staff, management, and affected employees. This is an electronic workflow process located on Arkema Intranet site. The management of change requests are controlled and tracked to completion. This process requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before implementation. 



Mechanical Integrity 

Arkema has well-established practices and procedures to maintain tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, transfer hoses, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include

: (1) developing written procedures, (2) conducting training, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  A preventative maintenance system (SAP) is used to track work orders, calibration schedules, testing and certification schedules, and completion of all the above. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the facility's process equipment. 



Operating Procedures 

Arkema maintains written procedures that provide detail on how to safely operate a process, including various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The procedures are maintained up-to-date by revising them as necessary. 



Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 

Arkema conducts reviews just prior to startup to ensure that new and modified facilities and processes are safe for operation.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 



Process Hazard Analysis

Arkema conducted a PHA in 2014 using the HAZOP/Layer of Protection Analysis.  The principal staff performing the PHA was the business Process Safety Engineer, Production Engineer, Operations Manager, Operations Technician.  There have been no significant changes to the VAM or Ammonia process at the facility since the preparation of the previous RMP and PHA.  



External Events Analysis

The 1999 RMPP seismic assessment of the facility estimated the seismic vulnerability of vessels, piping, and associated equipment and structu

res containing regulated substances.  In addition, vessels not containing regulated substances but which could impact vessels or piping containing regulated substances during a large earthquake were also evaluated.  The 1999 RMPP seismic review was performed according to the requirements in the 1998 Guidance for CalARP Seismic Assessment.  AECOM reviewed the seismic assessment portion of the RMPP seismic assessment conducted in December 1995, the October 1999 seismic update for the facility, and ENSR's Review of CalARP Seismic Assessment and Walkthrough Findings for the facility conducted in December 2003.  After the review, AECOM conducted a walkthrough at the facility to confirm whether recommended modifications had been completed.

Based on AECOM's review of the recommendations provided in the 1999 seismic assessment, the 2003 seismic update, and a walkthrough of the facility, it appears that the modifications recommended in those assessments have been adequately implemented.  No additional areas of concern were identified during AECOM's walkthrough. The seismic study was revalidated in 2009.  



Process Safety Information 

Arkema keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date and available to operating personnel. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs).  For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, pressure and level control) in the Operating Procedures The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, automated operating systems, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 

The facil

ity maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a means for establishing inspection and maintenance activities. 



Safe Work/Hot Work Practices 

Arkema has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. 



Training/Certification Programs 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Arkema has implemented a comprehensive training and certification program for all employees involved in operating a process.  After employees demonstrate having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration), they are certified to work independently.  In addition, trained technical staff is available 24 hours a day to support operations. 





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

In the last five years there has not been an accident or incident involving a release of Vinyl Acetate or aqueous ammonia from affected systems at the facility that resulted in an on-site death, injury, or property damage; or a known off-site death, injury, evacuation, shelter-in-place, property damage or environmental damage.

The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including: 

* Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, 

* Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation,

* Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, 

* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements (if a release occurs), and 

* Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment. 

The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. 

The overall emergency response program for Arkema in Torrance is coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department.  Arkema conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the appropriate emergency response organizations. 

In addition, the Arkema Response to Accidents in Transit (REACTS) team responds to accidental releases from transportation incidents occurring in the continental U.S. 

The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department. 





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Arkema completes a thorough review of the affected VAM / Ammonia system(s) each time a design change is implemented and reviews the standard operating procedures every three years.
